repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - Sahel Integrated Lowland
            Ecosystem Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Sahel Integrated Lowland
            Ecosystem Management (SILEM) Project for Burkina Faso were
            as follows outcomes were satisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was low or negligible; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory and borrower performance was
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: indicators must
            be realistic, feasible and available at the time the project
            is launched. A well-prepared logical framework (i.e., a
            results-based monitoring framework) should be the backbone
            of project design and should be fully specified and agreed
            prior to implementation. An Integrated Ecosystem Management
            (IEM) approach focusing on inter-village cohesion built on a
            common interest in the protection of shared watersheds is a
            successful model. SILEM was innovative as it brought
            together villages located in a watershed area and created a
            common interest among them based on an integrated management
            plan to protect the watershed.  This approach of developing
            a common vision across interested villages allows for a
            coherent organization and management of different
            occupations (farmers/cultivators and cattle farmers) based
            on the recognition the performance in each business depends
            on the common management of the shared watershed. The
            success of this approach was also reflected in the decline
            in social conflict in the areas where SILEM intervened.
            Formal and informal mechanisms were both required to ensure
            the sustainability of the investment.

repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - Sahel Integrated Lowland
            Ecosystem Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The purpose of the Sahel Integrated
            Lowland Ecosystem Management Project, is the sustainable
            improvement in the productive capacity of rural resources
            (natural, physical, human, and financial) in selected
            sub-watersheds. It aims at providing local governments, and
            rural communities with adequate capacity, and incentives for
            improving the natural resource base, thereby reducing
            poverty and vulnerability. Local capacity building for
            integrated ecosystem management will seek to strengthen the
            technical, and organizational capacity of rural communities,
            and municipalities to plan, implement and monitor integrated
            ecosystem management (IEM) activities. Financed activities
            include awareness building, and training on IEM concepts,
            land/water use planning, and environmental issues, in
            addition to the development of watershed management
            committees. To support such activities, a local investment
            fund will be developed, and have two windows: one for
            financing village and inter-village subprojects for
            watershed management, and, a special window to provide
            provinces with resources to undertake larger investments. An
            institutional capacity building for integrated ecosystem
            management shall provide an adequate policy environment,
            supporting civil society groups, and decentralized
            government institutions, so that through policy dialogues,
            IEM practices would be adopted. Also provided, will be
            training on information, negotiation and conflict
            resolution, supply of equipment, and, incremental operating
            costs. To support this objective, capacities will be
            strengthened to mobilize national, and international funds
            to address environmental, and resource management issues of
            local, regional, and potentially global significance.
            Project coordination, administration, and monitoring and
            evaluation activities will be financed.

repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - Sahel Integrated Lowland
            Ecosystem Management Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Sahel Integrated Lowland Ecosystem
            Management Program (SILEM) will provide support for
            environmental and natural resource management related
            activities of the Community-Based Rural Development Project
            (CBRDP). The potential environmental and social impacts of
            CBRDP and SILEM will vary in significance according to the
            size and strategic influence of sub-projects. Potential
            environmental and social risks of SILEM are in the areas of:
            planning for land use; exclusion of vulnerable social groups
            or disadvantaged groups from planning or distribution; soil
            and water management; displacement of population or
            non-agricultural species; dependence on seed distribution;
            pressure on land and water resources, biodiversity, or
            cultural properties; potential conflict among participants;
            health and environmental risks (especially associated with
            agro-minerals and organic manure); and potential for
            involuntary resettlement issues. The report sets forth an
            Environment and Social Management Framework (ESMF) to be
            used to avoid, manage, or mitigate the above impacts and
            whose details will be integrated into the sub-project cycle.

            Ecosystem Management Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Sahel Integrated Lowland Ecosystem
            Management Program (SILEM) will provide support for
            environmental and natural resource management related
            activities of the Community-Based Rural Development Project
            (CBRDP). The potential environmental and social impacts of
            CBRDP and SILEM will vary in significance according to the
            size and strategic influence of sub-projects. Potential
            environmental and social risks of SILEM are in the areas of:
            planning for land use; exclusion of vulnerable social groups
            or disadvantaged groups from planning or distribution; soil
            and water management; displacement of population or
            non-agricultural species; dependence on seed distribution;
            pressure on land and water resources, biodiversity, or
            cultural properties; potential conflict among participants;
            health and environmental risks (especially associated with
            agro-minerals and organic manure); and potential for
            involuntary resettlement issues. The report sets forth an
            Environment and Social Management Framework (ESMF) to be
            used to avoid, manage, or mitigate the above impacts and
            whose details will be integrated into the sub-project cycle.

Burkina Faso - Sahel Integrated Lowland
            Ecosystem Management Project : resettlement policy framework

abstracts.cdata!:
The Sahel Integrated Lowland Ecosystem
            Management Program (SILEM) will provide support for
            environmental and natural resource management related
            activities of the Community-Based Rural Development Project
            (CBRDP). The CBRDP and SILEM are generally expected to cause
            little or no significant adverse impacts in the areas of
            land acquisition and resettlement. Possible areas of impact
            are in loss of land or loss of access to productive and
            other resources. The resettlement policy framework (RPF)
            identifies and sets forth principles and procedures for
            compensation to negatively affected persons. Resettlement
            planning will be mainstreamed into the project design to
            ensure development activities are appropriately screened for
            potential impacts.
